title: Fire and Fury
added: On January 7, Bannon issued a statement calling Trump Jr. a "patriot and a good man," saying that his comments were directed at [[Paul Manafort]], not Trump Jr.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/07/us/politics/stephen-miller-cnn-trump-bannon-apology.html |title=Bannon Tries Backing Away From Explosive Comments |first1=Jeremy W. |last1=Peters |first2=Michael |last2=Tackett |date=January 7, 2018 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=January 8, 2018 | url-status=live |archivedate=January 8, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180108222407/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/07/us/politics/stephen-miller-cnn-trump-bannon-apology.html  }}</ref> The next day, on [[MSNBC]]'s ''[[Morning Joe]]'', Wolff denied that Bannon had been talking about Manafort.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/nation/index.ssf/2018/01/michael_wolff_author_of_fire_a.html |title=Michael Wolff, author of "Fire and Fury," contradicts Bannon's explanation |agency=Associated Press |work=The Plain Dealer |date=January 8, 2018 |accessdate=January 8, 2018 |url-status=live |archivedate=January 9, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180109180854/http://www.cleveland.com/nation/index.ssf/2018/01/michael_wolff_author_of_fire_a.html }}</ref>

Also on January 7, White House senior policy adviser [[Stephen Miller (political advisor)|Stephen Miller]], speaking on CNN's ''[[State of the Union (American TV program)|State of the Union]],'' said: "The book is best understood as a work of very poorly written fiction, and I also will say that the author is a garbage author of a garbage book."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Daniella|first1=Silva|title=Stephen Miller slams 'Fire and Fury' as 'grotesque work of fiction' in tense interview |date=January 7, 2018 |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/stephen-miller-slams-fire-fury-grotesque-work-fiction-tense-interview-n835371|website=NBC News|accessdate=January 9, 2018 |url-status=live |archivedate=January 13, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180113060625/https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/donald-trump/stephen-miller-slams-fire-fury-grotesque-work-fiction-tense-interview-n835371}}</ref> In a January 8 interview with [[Dana Loesch]], [[Mike Pence|Vice President Mike Pence]] described ''Fire and Fury'' as a "book of fiction." He stated that he had not read it, and would not read it, but that reports concerning its contents did not accord with his experience of working with President Trump.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/mike-pence-dismisses-fire-and-fury-as-book-of-fiction/article/2645313 |first=Sarah |last=Westwood |title=Mike Pence dismisses 'Fire and Fury' as 'book of fiction'|date=January 8, 2017|work=[[Washington Examiner]]}}</ref> Over the weekend of January 6â€“7, [[Rebekah Mercer]], a conservative donor who worked with Bannon on Trump's 2016 campaign and as a part-owner of [[Breitbart News]], distanced herself from Bannon, saying she would no longer provide him with financial backing.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newsday.com/news/nation/bannon-trump-rebekah-mercer-1.15941844 |title=Bannon faces the loss of key backers: Trump and Rebekah Mercer|author=Ngo, Emily|work=Newsday|date=January 7, 2018|accessdate=January 9, 2018}}</ref> On January 9, Bannon announced that he would leave Breitbart News.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-42628201|title=Steve Bannon leaves Breitbart News amid Trump row|work=BBC News|date=January 9, 2018|accessdate=January 9, 2018}}</ref>
